The '''{{PAGENAME}}''' is a portfolio proposed by [[William F. Sharpe]]. It consists of global stocks and bonds, held in [[Free-float methodology|free-float]] market proportions.<ref name=RISMAT-7>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=Retirement Income Scenario Matrices 7. The Market Portfolio|url=https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/RISMAT/RISMAT-7.pdf|publisher=Stanford University (Creative Commons)|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref>
== Components ==
There is currently no single retail fund that implements a World Bond/Stock (WBS) portfolio in the way described by Sharpe. To address this, he has suggested a four-fund proxy<ref name=RISMAT-7/><ref name=4-Fund-Proxy>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=The Four-fund Proxy for the World Bond Stock Fund|url=https://retirementincomeanalysis.blogspot.com/2019/08/the-four-fund-proxy-for-wold-bond-stock.html|date=August 2019|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> and also a two-fund proxy<ref name=2-Fund-Proxy>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=A Two-fund Proxy for the World Bond Stock Fund|url=https://retirementincomeanalysis.blogspot.com/2019/09/a-two-fund-proxy-for-world-bond-stock.html|date=September 2019|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> for WBS consisting of established Vanguard index funds.
A four-fund proxy for WBS consists of:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Component fund !! Asset class |- | VTSAX (or VTI) || US stocks |- | VTIAX (or VXUS) || Ex-US stocks |- | VBTLX (or BND) || USD bonds |- | VTABX (or BNDX) || Ex-USD bonds |- |}
A two-fund proxy for WBS consists of:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Component fund !! Asset class |- | VT || Global stocks |- | BNDW || Global bonds |- |}
Of course, it is also possible to implement something similar with non-Vanguard funds.
== Allocations ==
The index funds used by the WBS proxies described above are held in proportion to their free-float market capitalization. That requires calculating the market capitalization of the index that each fund tracks. This is done by taking each index's market capitalization listed in its most recent factsheet, and then projecting that forward by the change in the fund's adjusted closing prices between the factsheet's publishing date and the current date.
<math> \mathrm{IndexMarketCap}_\mathrm{Current} = \mathrm{IndexMarketCap}_\mathrm{Factsheet} \times \frac{\mathrm{TrackingFundPrice}_\mathrm{Current}}{\mathrm{TrackingFundPrice}_{\mathrm{FactsheetDate}}} </math>
Note: VBTLX/BND, VTABX/BNDX, and BNDW track Bloomberg indices which do not publish their market capitalization numbers. Sharpe has suggested that FTSE indexes (for example, WorldBIG) could substitute.<ref name=RISMAT-7/><ref name=4-Fund-Proxy/>
=== Example ===
Here is an example of the allocation calculations as of June 15, 2025:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Component fund ! Asset class ! Tracked index ! Index factsheet market cap ! Index factsheet date ! Adjusted closing price on factsheet date ! Latest adjusted closing price (June 15, 2025) ! Projected market cap (June 15, 2025) ! Allocation (June 15, 2025) |- | VT | Global stocks | FTSE Global All Cap Index | $90.42T | May 30, 2025 | $123.37 | $124.95 | $91.58T (= $90.42T * $124.95 / $123.37) | 62.43% (= $91.58T / ($55.08T + $91.58T)) |- | BNDW | Global bonds | FTSE WorldBIG (substitute for Bloomberg index) | $54.93T | May 31, 2025 | $68.58 | $68.77 | $55.08T (= $54.93T * $68.77 / $68.58) | 37.57% (= $55.08T / ($55.08T + $91.58T)) |- |}
=== Current allocations ===
Here are the current allocations for the four-fund proxy, updated in real time:
{| border="1" style="border-collapse: collapse; |- |{{#widget:Google Spreadsheet |key=2PACX-1vQShEGnLTHNk2_zgHWTiReXADEhmNvLR8SIaTsdGTdQJaa_F9ESrbo8bcsP0XEsVlBFtGEbjqUMO7g_ |oid=1905516517 |width=450 |height=280 }} |- |Source: [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1VFfGgf-oscxsnyjHLsdIGNa5WfxI00XG_51xxr5VUn4/edit#gid=717958008 GMP: Global Market Portfolio] |}
Here are the current allocations for the two-fund proxy, updated in real time:
{| border="1" style="border-collapse: collapse; |- |{{#widget:Google Spreadsheet |key=2PACX-1vQShEGnLTHNk2_zgHWTiReXADEhmNvLR8SIaTsdGTdQJaa_F9ESrbo8bcsP0XEsVlBFtGEbjqUMO7g_ |oid=912172076 |width=450 |height=280 }} |- |Source: [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1VFfGgf-oscxsnyjHLsdIGNa5WfxI00XG_51xxr5VUn4/edit#gid=717958008 GMP: Global Market Portfolio] |}
Note: The total allocation to VTI and VXUS in the four-fund proxy might not precisely equal the VT allocation in the two-fund proxy. This is because VTI tracks a [[CRSP equity indexes|CRSP]] index which differs slightly from the [[FTSE Group|FTSE]] index that VT tracks.
== Rebalancing == {{See also|Rebalancing}}
The World Bond/Stock (WBS) portfolio holds each individual asset (that is, individual stock or bond) in proportion to its free-float market capitalization. Equivalently, it holds the same fraction of each asset’s free-float shares outstanding. That is, '''(shares held) / (free-float shares outstanding)''' is the same for every individual asset.
Framing WBS this way shows that rebalancing is needed only when an asset’s free-float supply changes the fraction of shares held (for example, new issuances, buybacks, or redemptions).
Conversely, events like price changes and dividend payments do ''not'' require rebalancing since they leave the fraction of shares held unchanged. As a result, WBS requires less frequent rebalancing than traditional fixed-weight portfolios (for example, a 60/40 stock/bond mix), which must rebalance whenever asset prices change.
If WBS assets are held through a ''single'' index fund, the fund handles rebalancing internally. But if assets are split across ''multiple funds'' (for example, stocks in VT and bonds in BNDW), their underlying free-float supply may change at different rates. This causes the share fractions held by the different funds to drift apart, requiring occasional manual rebalancing between the funds to realign them.
== Adjusting for personal circumstances ==
The World Bond/Stock portfolio mirrors the holdings of the average publicly invested portfolio, thereby taking on average investment risk and producing average return.<ref name=Arithmetic>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=The Arithmetic of Active Management|url=https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/art/active/active.htm|publisher=Association for Investment Management and Research|date=February 1991|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> This makes it a good default strategy.
Nevertheless, Sharpe notes that someone may justifiably deviate from this strategy to adjust for personal circumstances.<ref name=Adjust>{{Cite web|author=Charles Rotblut, William F. Sharpe|title=Allocate by Market Weight (And Adjust for Personal Circumstances)|url=https://www.aaii.com/files/PDF/9314_allocate-by-market-weight-and-adjust-for-personal-circumstances.pdf|publisher=American Association of Individual Investors|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> Adjustments discussed by Sharpe include: * '''Adding a riskless asset.''' For example, using certain inflation-adjusted investments (like [[Treasury Inflation Protected Security|TIPS]]) to cover a portion of real expenses.<ref name=RISMAT-6>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=Retirement Income Analysis with scenario matrices, Chapter 6. Inflation-Protected Investments|url=https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/RISMAT/RISMAT-6.pdf|publisher=Stanford University (Creative Commons)|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> * '''Tilting asset allocations.''' For example, adjusting the stock/bond ratio to account for factors like [[Human capital|human capital]].<ref name=Adjust/>
=== Tilting using adaptive asset allocation ===
Sharpe proposes Adaptive Asset Allocation Policies, which allow asset class tilting while still remaining anchored to the dynamics of the WBS portfolio.<ref name=AAAP>{{Cite web|author=William F. Sharpe|title=Adaptive Asset Allocation Policies |url=https://web.stanford.edu/~wfsharpe/aaap/wfsaaap.pdf|publisher=Stanford University|accessdate=June 16, 2025}}</ref> This enables customization while continuously adapting to changes in the relative risk between asset classes.
It works as follows. Start with a desired initial allocation. Then update each asset class weight using:
<math> \mathrm{UpdatedWeight} = \mathrm{CurrentMarketWeight} \times \frac{\mathrm{InitialDesiredWeight}}{\mathrm{InitialMarketWeight}} </math>
Finally, normalize the updated weights to get the new allocation. For example:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Component fund ! Asset class ! Initial desired weight ! Initial market weight ! Current market weight ! Updated weight ! Normalized allocation |- | VT | Global stocks | 80% | 60% | 55% | 73.33% (= 55% * 80/60) | 76.52% (= 73.33 / (73.33 + 22.50)) |- | BNDW | Global bonds | 20% | 40% | 45% | 22.50% (=45% * 20/40) | 23.48% (= 22.50 / (73.33 + 22.50)) |- |}
